facts.text: Appellant has a factory for making yarn out of jute with Spinning and Batching departments.
Ramdhani and Sitaram were Sardars employed in the Spinning Department.
On March 22, 1958, Roving Sardar Jagabandhu of Batching Department informed Ghosh (in charge of Batching) that Ramdhani was throwing away workable rove slivers as unusable.
Ghosh went to Spinning Department, confirmed the report, and asked Jagabandhu to collect the thrown away roves for complaint to superior authority.
Ramdhani tried to prevent Jagabandhu from collecting the roves, took a menacing attitude, and abused Ghosh in filthy language upon Ghosh's intervention.
Sitaram, another Sardar in Spinning Department, joined, abused Ghosh, and threatened him with violence.

Ghosh complained to Management; charge-sheets served on Ramdhani and Sitaram on 26-3-58 stating they used abusive filthy language and threatened to assault Ghosh, guilty of misconduct under Standing Order No. 14(c)(i).

Enquiry held by appellant's Labour Officer; both workmen accepted Jagabandhu's statement proving insubordination; they refused charge-sheets; fomented stay-in strike by other Sardars on 24th and 25th March 1958 causing dislocation.
Labour Officer found them guilty of insubordination and subversive activities; dismissal orders issued.

Union raised industrial dispute; referred to Second Labour Court, West Bengal; award dated January 7, 1960 holding dismissal unjustified, directing reinstatement without wages for forced unemployment period, treated as leave without pay.
Appellant conceded before tribunal that Ghosh was not supervisor of Spinning Department and not direct superior of Ramdhani and Sitaram.

Tribunal held no insubordination as Ghosh not superior; enquiry findings erroneous; other matters (refusal of charge-sheets, strike) not charged, could not be considered; conduct improper hence no back wages.
Supreme Court accepted facts as true; workmen guilty of imputed misconduct.
Ramdhani got weekly wages, not dependent on out-turn.

legal_issues.text: Whether the conduct of Ramdhani and Sitaram amounted to wilful insubordination or disobedience under Standing Order No. 14(c)(i), even though Ghosh was not their direct superior.
Whether the dismissal order could be sustained despite enquiry officer mentioning refusal to accept charge-sheets and causing stay-in strike, which were not in charge-sheets.
Whether the dismissal was an instance of victimisation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Workmen guilty of misconduct under Standing Order 14(c)(i) by abusing and threatening Ghosh who was trying to collect evidence of wastefulness for management.
Dismissal based on charge of insubordination; incidental matters in enquiry report connected and corroborative.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: N. Kalindi v. Tata Locomotive Engineering Co. Ltd.

respondent_arguments.text: Insubordination requires disobedience to direct superior or prescribed rule; Ghosh not superior of Spinning Department workmen.
Ramdhani entitled to throw away unworkable roves as remuneration depended on out-turn.
Dismissal induced by uncharged findings on refusal of charge-sheets and stay-in strike; no opportunity to defend.

court_reasoning.text: Facts true; workmen guilty of misconduct; Standing Order 14(c)(i) covers wilful insubordination broadly, including defiance of persons in authority whether direct superiors or not, and riotous conduct impeding higher officers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Insubordination and disobedience are different categories; not limited to direct superiors.

court_reasoning.text: Implied rule that higher officers not thwarted from reporting wastefulness; conduct was wilful insubordination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ramdhani on weekly wages, not out-turn based.

court_reasoning.text: Dismissal order based solely on charge finding; incidental matters connected, corroborative, relevant for punishment; not too legalistic view.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order sustainable if based on charge opportunity met.
Workmen did not suggest victimisation in evidence.

holdings.text: Conduct amounted to wilful insubordination under Standing Order 14(c)(i) even if Ghosh not direct superior.
Dismissal order rightly based on charged misconduct; incidental connected matters legitimately considered.

precedents_cited.case_name: N. Kalindi v. Tata Locomotive Engineering Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Order of dismissal sustainable if based on finding on charge even if other incidental matters crept in during enquiry.

statutes_cited.name: Standing Orders
statutes_cited.relevance: Misconduct: wilful insubordination or disobedience of lawful reasonable order of superior.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; tribunal's award set aside as erroneous; dismissals of Ramdhani and Sitaram justified as guilty of insubordination under Standing Order 14(c)(i).

key_quotes.text: "We are entirely unable to agree with the tribunal that the conduct of the workmen did not amount to wilful insubordination."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects tribunal's core finding on insubordination.

key_quotes.text: "In our view, insubordination would include defiance of persons in authority whether such persons were the direct superiors of the workmen charged or not."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "An order of dismissal may be rightly sustained if it is based on a finding on a charge which the workmen concerned had the opportunity of meeting even though in the course of the enquiry other incidental matters had crept in."
key_quotes.speaker: court
